awd_titl_txt: (CAREER) Real-Time Detection, Monitoring and Characterization of Single Nanoparticle/Bioaerosol Using On-Chip Resonators
awd_abstract_narration:
Objective: 
The research objective of this project is to explore and develop a new label free optical technique to achieve portable, inexpensive and high resolution devices capable of real time, in situ detection of particles to address issues faced by conventional particle counters/spectrometers. Specifically, we will investigate and exploit mode splitting in ultra high quality Whispering Gallery Mode optical resonators for ultrasensitive, realtime, insitu monitoring and characterization of nanoparticles with various chemical and physical properties at single particle resolution.

Intellectual Merit: 
Real time, in situ single particle detection and characterization will lay the groundwork to investigate the dynamics and properties of individual nanoparticles and effectively utilize them to develop innovative products. However, most conventional macroscale methods only allow ensemble measurement of nanoparticles, revealing average behaviors of the nanoparticle systems. Our chip scale microscopic sensing device provides label free, single particle resolution, self referencing feature, and superior noise immunity for real time, in situ measurements at ambient conditions, which constitutes a significant advancement compared to existing schemes.

Broader Impact: 
The interdisciplinary nature of this work encourages collaborations with groups in environmental engineering, biology and physics to explore new classes of spectroscopy for characterizing the interactions between particles, molecules, and ligands. The success of this project will have significant impacts on materials science, chemical analysis, energy, biomedicine, communication, instrumentation, and metrology for nanotechnology. The PI will develop education programs in which students at different levels can obtain broad knowledge and diverse technical skills in nanoscience and technology. She will leverage the existing outreach programs between Washington University and surrounding communities to foster and promote understanding of nanotechnology among the general public.

por.por_cntn:
With the rapid progress in nanotechnology, nanoparticles of different chemical compositions and sizes have been synthesized and used extensively as key components in various applications from optical and electronic devices to biomedical diagnostics and pharmaceutical industries. Meanwhile, nanoparticles as end/by-products of industrial processes have become sources of exposure posing risks to humans and environment. The World Health Organization estimates around 2 million premature deaths worldwide caused by airborne chemical and biological particles. As the interests in nanoparticle applications and their risks to health are growing, there is an urgent need in assessing their benefits and risks. A critical step in this assessment is to establish reliable techniques for real-time, in-situ detection and characterization of individual nanoparticles in various media. This will facilitate understanding the size dependent properties of nanoparticles for developing innovative products and assess toxicology of nanoparticles with different feature sizes. It will also lay the groundwork to investigate dynamics and properties of particle formations and interactions at single nanoparticle resolution, which will help understand the systems in microscopic scale.

In this project, we demonstrated the first micro-resonator based particle sensors that can achieve not only detection but also sizing of single nanoparticles one by one. My group has successfully demonstrated the first on-chip single nanoparticle detection and accurate sizing in a single-shot measurement using mode-splitting technique, a method built on a phenomenon arising from light scattering induced by single nanoparticles in ultra-high-quality WGM resonators fabricated in my laboratory at Washington University. Specifically, when a nanoparticle enters the light field of an optical mode in a whispering-gallery-mode resonator, it will trigger light scattering, which will subsequently induce mode splitting, i.e., one resonance splits into two, in the transmission spectra of the resonator. The two spectrally shifted split modes are triggered by the nanoparticle induced light scattering and therefore carry information of the nanoparticle. Moreover, the two split modes reside in the same resonator and experience the same noises, forming a self-referenced detection scheme. The technique provides superior noise suppression to other kinds of micro/nano photonic sensors in ambient conditions and enables the detection and precise size  measurement of single nanoparticles with a single-shot measurement in a microscale device for the first time.

We demonstrated, for the first time, real-time, label-free, in-situ detection and size measurement of individual single influenza A virions and metallic nanoparticles as they continuously arrived to the resonator one by one using the mode-splitting technique. The developed theoretical model and experimental techniques allow spectrometry of individual Influenza virions, polystyrene and gold nanoparticles, with a detection limit of 20 nm. These are the smallest sizes measured using an optical resonator or other intra-cavity light scattering schemes. Moreover, we have demonstrated that our approach allows identifying the components of mixtures of different particles.

We also developed a new self-referenced and self-heterodyned sensing scheme by integrating an ultra-narrow-linewidth microlaser with the self-referenced mode-splitting technique.
